paper.title: SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccines sensitize tumours to immune checkpoint blockade

core_question: Does intratumoral SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination prime tumors to respond more effectively to anti-PD-L1 checkpoint blockade?

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Mouse combination therapy cohort
datasets_or_cohorts.sample_size_or_observations: 78 tumor-bearing mice pooled across repeat experiments
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Preclinical cohort testing intratumoral mRNA vaccine plus anti-PD-L1 therapy for tumor control in multiple murine models.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Mouse matched control cohorts
datasets_or_cohorts.sample_size_or_observations: 84 tumor-bearing mice across vaccine-only, ICI-only, and vehicle groups
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Matched control tumors evaluating vaccine-only, ICI-only, and vehicle treatments without combined therapy.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Retrospective metastatic patient cohort
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Retrospective analysis comparing ICI outcomes by prior SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination status among metastatic patients.

major_limitations: The human analysis is retrospective, non-randomized, and likely confounded.
Vaccination timing relative to ICI initiation varied across patients.
Tumor-type mix and treatment-history heterogeneity limit direct causal interpretation.
Mouse model effects may not map one-to-one to all human tumors.
